text.p: The following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
KOMMERSANT DAILY
- Russia's draft Tax Code, aimed at easing the tax burden on individuals and encouraging foreign investment, was preliminarily approved by the State Duma on Thursday.
- Russia has launched one of the largest issues of 10-year Eurobonds worth $2 billion.
- The Central Bank of Russia is planning some new rules to regulate Russia's securities market.
- A number of leading tobacco giants are planning to expand their presence in Russia.
- St Petersburg, Russia's second city, has prepared a new document to encourage foreign investments in the region.
- South Korea's Daewoo is to start producing television sets in St Petersburg, investing about $10 million by the end of the year.
SEVODNYA
- Russia's Nizhnevartovskneftegaz, the main production unit of Tyumen oil company, is likely to be declared bankrupt next week, according to the government commision on economic issues.
- President Boris Yeltsin signed a decree on Thursday on slashing gas prices for industrial enterprises.
- The first auction of regional securities is to take place on Friday.
NEZAVISIMAYA GAZETA
- Russia will enjoy full rights in Denver but will not become a fully fledged member of a Group of Eight leading industrial powers.
- Russia's Atomic Ministry supports a project to store nuclear wastes in the Pacific.
- About 600,000 enterprises have been accused of tax evasion in the last three months, Deputy Prime Minister Antoly Kulikov says.
ROSSIISKIYE VESTI
- Russian parliamentarians are paid 7.5 million roubles a month ($1,302). The average monthly salary in Russia is about 800,000 roubles, or about $140.
- Russia's Communist Party will hold its regular central committee plenum at the end of June to discuss policy.
- St Petersburg is planning to hold a referendum in protest against the local govenor's housing reforms.
MOSKOVSKY KOMSOMOLETS
- One of the top officials in the gas exporting division of the huge Gazprom company was injured on Thursday in a bomb explosion.
--Tatyana Ustinova, Moscow Newsroom, +7095 841 8520.
